Description: A sealing from a document, impressed from a gem or metal finger-ring, with a draped portrait bust of a late Ptolemaic ruler to right; he wears a wide diadem, with curls falling in front of the ears and extending to whiskers. The back has an impression of the papyrus document to which it was attached, with a hole for the binding string. Red-brown Nile silt.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: San el-Hagar (Tanis), House "M", in north-west of main temple enclosure.
Curator's comments: Petrie, Tanis I (1885): 34, pl.12 [14]; Stanwick, P.E. Egyptian Royal Sculptures of the Ptolemaic Period (PhD, New York 1999): pl. 209. Stanwick, Portraits of the Ptolemies (2002): 61; fig. 244 See Favard-Meeks in Brissaud and Zivie-Coche: Tanis 1987-1997 (1998) p.114.

Terracotta IV Donated: Egypt Exploration Fund. From Find 15 at Tanis, a Ptolemaic house within the great enclosure wall, about 200 feet north of the Monumental West Gate. This house is marked M on the plan (Petrie 1885: pl. [xvii]). 3632 comes from the same house. Ptolemaic, between about 116 and 51 BC. All the material from Find 15 is said to be of Ptolemaic date: the excavator (Petrie) suggests the end of the Ptolemaic dynasty, and a hoard of coins of Cleopatra VII was found there (Favard-Meeks 1998: 164n. 102). There are various possibilities for this portrait: Ptolemy IX Soter II (compare Walker and Higgs 2001: 67, no. 45); Ptolemy XI Alexander II (compare Kyrieleis 1975: pl. 55:15 and 16); Ptolemy XII Neos Dionysos (compare Smith 1988: pl. 75:20). Bibliog: Petrie 1885: 34, pl. xii:14; Favard-Meeks 1998: 11, pl. xii:14.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3616)
